body:
OS = kernel + userspace
```
kernel:
1,2: https://github.com/torvalds/linux
3: https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/master/Makefile
4: https://lkml.org/
```
```
GNU:
1,2: https://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/coreutils.git
3: https://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/coreutils.git/tree/Makefile.am (for Automake)
4: https://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/coreutils/
```
Of course there are a few more userspace components to the fully usable OS like a bootloader. Refer to LFS documentation for the rest.
body_html:
OS = kernel + userspace

kernel:
1,2: https://github.com/torvalds/linux
3: https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/master/Makefile
4: https://lkml.org/

GNU:
1,2: https://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/coreutils.git
3: https://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/coreutils.git/tree/Makefile.am (for Automake)
4: https://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/coreutils/

Of course there are a few more userspace components to the fully usable OS like a bootloader. Refer to LFS documentation for the rest.

body: I don’t think you understand how an os works, the reason there isn’t a single repo for most os’ is because they are made up of modules that have to be compiled together, theyre more complex then your average program. As for react os’ issues tab, problems are kept track of on their community pages which you can look up on your own. Do a bit of research, look  up lfs if you really want to learn more about how to make an operating system.
body_html: I don’t think you understand how an os works, the reason there isn’t a single repo for most os’ is because they are made up of modules that have to be compiled together, theyre more complex then your average program. As for react os’ issues tab, problems are kept track of on their community pages which you can look up on your own. Do a bit of research, look up lfs if you really want to learn more about how to make an operating system.

body:
1. It's [Linux](https://kernel.org) + [Gnu Core utils](https://www.gnu.org/software/coreutils/) + whatever other packages you install on top of it. If you install openbox then look up the repo/makefile/bug tracker for openbox. You seem to think that because there isn't one single massive repository with everything in it then it's not open source. That's retarded. All Linux based OSs are a loose collection of separately developed pieces of software *by design*. So the sources for the various pieces of software that make up an OS are going to be hosted all over the place.

2. See links above. Granted if you install a package from a repo which isn't open source then it's not "totally" open source, but you could make sure to only install open source packages or use a flavor of linux which only has free & open source packages like gnewsense.

3. Again, you seem to think that because there isn't one monolithic makefile then an OS isn't open source. Look up how to build individual software packages individually you absolute gremlin.

4. Bug trackers for each piece of software are going to be hosted on individual projects' sites.

TL;DR you seem to lack a basic understanding of what an OS even is.
body_html:
1. It's Linux + Gnu Core utils + whatever other packages you install on top of it. If you install openbox then look up the repo/makefile/bug tracker for openbox. You seem to think that because there isn't one single massive repository with everything in it then it's not open source. That's retarded. All Linux based OSs are a loose collection of separately developed pieces of software by design. So the sources for the various pieces of software that make up an OS are going to be hosted all over the place.

  2. See links above. Granted if you install a package from a repo which isn't open source then it's not "totally" open source, but you could make sure to only install open source packages or use a flavor of linux which only has free & open source packages like gnewsense.

  3. Again, you seem to think that because there isn't one monolithic makefile then an OS isn't open source. Look up how to build individual software packages individually you absolute gremlin.

  4. Bug trackers for each piece of software are going to be hosted on individual projects' sites.

TL;DR you seem to lack a basic understanding of what an OS even is.

body: Linux From Scratch isn’t “coding an OS from scratch.” It’s a minimal Linux system you compile yourself exclusively from source code. It’s called “from scratch” because it doesn’t use any binaries that others have compiled for you. It’s entirely made from open source code you download and compile yourself.
body_html: Linux From Scratch isn’t “coding an OS from scratch.” It’s a minimal Linux system you compile yourself exclusively from source code. It’s called “from scratch” because it doesn’t use any binaries that others have compiled for you. It’s entirely made from open source code you download and compile yourself.
